Frequently Asked Questions

Import and Export

Who can apply?

  1. The DIRECT EXPORTER, that is the firm or individual whose name appears on the import/export entry or declaration, is the party entitled to drawback. However, the right to drawback can be endorsed by the exporter to a supplier.
  2. An INDIRECT EXPORTER, such as an importer, manufacturer or merchant that supplied duty-paid materials for exports, can claim drawback if:
    1. the exporter waives the right to drawback by endorsing the Form C.3 (The Drawback Debenture Form) and sharing the export documents; and
    2. proof of delivery of duty paid goods, from the importer who paid the duties through to the direct exporter is provided

How fast is payment made?

The Government of Sierra Leone is yet to establish an escrow account with the Bank of Sierra Leone into which monies are paid for the purpose of satisfying the duty drawback and rebates needs of importers and1 exporters.

Is there a time limit for claims?

Duty drawback can be claimed only within twelve (12) months from the date of your first export. It is, however, advisable to put in your claim quarterly i.e. every four (4) months.

How long shall i wait?

Where documents submitted are authenticated, the maximum period for processing the claim i.e. from date of submission to the time of payments, should not exceed one months.

How do i claim drawback?

Submit an application for claim of the drawback together with the under-listed documents to the Commissioner for approval for processing at the Long Room:

  1. Certified copies of the import documents
  2. Import duty payment receipts (or certified copies)
  3. Drawback Debenture Form

When is drawback due?

It is due when there is ample evidence that the goods have duly been re-exported the evidence being:

  1. Either Sierra Leone Customs export documents endorsed by Customs authorities in both the exporting and importing countries or
  2. A “landing certificate” from the importing country (where required).

Who benefits from duty drawback?

Any person/firm who imports finished products and re-exports them or any manufacturer who uses imported raw materials in the manufacture of products and exports them is entitled to claim a duty drawback.

Legal background

The Duty Drawback Regime is legally backed by sections 45 of the Customs Act 2011

What is duty drawback?

  • This is a refund on import duties after the importer re exports previously imported products (Same-state Drawback).
  • It is also a refund of import duties paid on imported raw materials used in the production of finished goods and exported (Material Drawback)

If both imported inputs and domestic inputs of the same, kind and quality are used to manufacture goods, which are exported, then drawback of the duty which was paid on the imported inputs is payable on the exports. It is immaterial
whether the actual imported input or the domestic input of the same kind and quality was used in the exported article.

My vehicle was cleared on exemption from payment of duty as a diplomat. How do I dispose of it after my duty tour?

You may apply to the Commissioner of Customs declaring your intention to sell the vehicle. You may attach copies of all relevant documents covering the vehicle to your application. The duties and taxes involved would be worked out for the buyer to pay.

What has cubic capacity and the age of a vehicle got to do with the duties and taxes on a vehicle?

Lets say A friend imported a VW Passat vehicle and paid taxes far lower than what I paid on a similar vehicle I imported. When I enquired, I was told that the cubic capacity and the age of my vehicle were different from that of my friend. Customs uses the Home Delivery value, the Cubic Capacity (CC) and the age (where the vehicle is more than 10 years old) to compute taxes on vehicles.

What rate of duty and taxes apply to the importation of vehicles?

All vehicles imported into the country whether exmepted specifically or otherwise attract the following:

  1. Import Duty - (0%, 5%, 20%, and 30%)

  2. Import GST - (0% or 15%)
  3. Withholding Tax - (3%)
  4. ECOWAS Levy - (0.5%)
  5. Processing fees of Le 30,000 per declaration

In addition, the right hand categories of vehicles attract overage shortage of 40% of CIF

Are there other obligations to be met by the vehicle importer?

stt any dealer/importer shall furnish the Commissioner of CEPS with the following information:

  1. the year of manufacture

  2. the make and model of the vehicle
  3. the name and address of the manufacturer of the vehicle and
  4. the home delivery value of the vehicle.

What is the first purchase price?

Section 90 (7) of the Law indicates that the “first purchase price”, means the “price at which the type of motor vehicle in question is usually sold for use when new by a dealer in the country of manufacture”.

Why does the Customs use the Home Delivery Value to determine the duties and taxes to be paid on a used vehicle but not the importers purchase price?

The importer’s purchase price is accepted when the imported vehicle is new. However for Customs purposes, the value of a used vehicle is deemed to be the Home Delivery Value (HDV) depreciated as provided plus freight and insurance (i.e. 0.875% of C & F) to arrive at Cost, Insurance and Freight (CIF) value.

To be fair to all importers bringing in vehicles from various countries all over the world, and considering the fact that prices differ from country to country and place to place, the Customs deems the use of the HDV as the most appropriate way of determining duties and taxes to be paid on vehicles.

How are vehicles categorized and identified for tax purposes?

By the engine capacity e.g. 1.6cc, 2.0cc, 2.5cc, etc.

  1. By the seating capacity e.g. 5, 10, 30, 50 persons
  2. By usage/purpose e.g. Buses, trucks, tippers, lorries etc
  3. By age

Does CED have up to date data on vehicles?

Yes. Data has been collected and collated on the values and ages of vehicles over the years. Manufacturers and dealers of motor vehicles are still assisting Customs to furnish the unit in charge with brochures, booklets and other documents which give the values and other information on the vehicles.

Are there any obligations to be met by vehicle dealers?

Yes. Section 8 on to 28 give details on importation and exportation of good: For this category of import the importer is required to furnish the following

  1. the year of manufacture
  2. the make and model of the vehicle
  3. the name and address of the manufacturer of the vehicle and
  4. the home delivery value of the vehicle (in principle).

Which type of vehicles have their ages falling under year of manufacture?

They are the vehicles whose age can be determined from charts based on the records of manufacturers’ batches of production. Such vehicles include:

German, Japanese and Dutch vehicles e.g. Mercedes Benz, M.A.N Diesel, Toyota, Nissan, DAF etc. These vehicles have their ages determined by reading a chart furnished by the dealers of the type of vehicle.

NOTE: The use of log sheets and seat belts alone to check or confirm the age of vehicles is not reliable. What is on log sheets are more often dates of first registration of such vehicles and not dates of manufacture.

What is a model year reckoning index?

The model year reckoning index vehicles are those whose ages can be determined from a letter in the 10th position in a 17 character rotation counting from the left. Such vehicles include:

  1. All US and Canadian vehicles
  2. All Korean vehicles
  3. Japan (Mitsubishi, Isuzu)
  4. German (Opel, VW, Audi)
  5. Sweden (Volvo, Saab)

For example, an Opel Vectra vehicle with the chassis number viz: WOL000087N1658971 is a 1992 model.

How is the age of a motor vehicle calculated?

The age of a motor vehicle imported under the law is calculated with effect from the year in which the motor vehicle was first manufactured. The age of a vehicle is a crucial determinant in valuation for duty purposes. In arriving at the age of vehicles, CED uses the model year reckoning index which normally gives a round year age point e.g. 1990 or 2000 or the dealer chart matrix.

What are the laws governing the importation of vehicles into Ghana?

The laws governing the importation of vehicles into Sierra Leone is the Customs Act 2011

What are the taxes on commonly imported commodities?

The various tax handles at customs are: import duty, import GST, Excise duties, Income Tax, and ECOWAS levy

Does Customs valuation assess duties on goods in similar containers equally? E.g. I wish to suggest that goods in 20-footer containers should attract equal duties.

This suggestion cannot be accepted where the contents are different. For example, importer “A” may import vehicle engines while importer “B” may go for used vehicle tires in two different containers. Since the two items are not the same, and therefore may attract different duties and taxes the CED cannot impose equal duties

My uncle wishes to go into the import of text books and educational materials. What are the taxes?

Educational materials, particularly text books, are free of duties and taxes.

I intend visiting Sierra Leone with my family this year with a portable TV set, radio and photographic materials and return with them after the visit. Will these attract duties?

Items temporarily imported for personal use are free from payment of duty but they will have to be declared to the Customs on the appropriate section dealing with such transactions who will issue an appropriate instruction on the entire process.

Can one import weapons (arms and ammunitions) into the country during a visit?

According to Sierra Leone laws, arms and ammunitions are restricted items and can only be imported after issuance of a special permit by the Ministry of Internal Affairs and the Sierra Leone police.

What are removal articles?

These include movable personal belongings or effects, domestic appliances, household provisions normally kept in stock, pet animals, and also any equipment necessary for the exercise of the calling, for the personal use of the passenger.

NOTE: Removal articles do not include arms, ammunitions and motor vehicles.

Does the importation of Malaria, Computers, Agricultural machineries attract import duties and taxes?

The Finance Acts 2010, and 2011 has concessions for the aforementioned items to be imported free of duty. Under the law, all agricultural and mining equipment are free of duty.

How to start the clearing process?

One can start the clearing processes by putting together the following documents.

  1. Original Bill of Lading/Airway Bill
  2. Attested Invoice(s)
  3. Packing List
  4. CVC
  5. LOCAL INSURANCE
  6. Tax Clearance Certificate
  7. TIN

Procedures:

  1. Fill and submit Customs Declaration electronically to CUSTOMS through the DTI Burreau - Where there is a remote DTI facility, complete the Single Administrative Document (SAD) at the premise of importer.
    1. When the Declaration is validated, pay relevant duties at the bank
    2. Proceed to the Customs Long room with hard copy of Declaration and other import pay-in-slip together with SAD to the Customs In gate section, documentary section and valuation for processing.
    3. Proceed to the Outdoor at the Queen Elizabeth second quay (where goods are deposited) for examination and/or release of goods

Is the CVC enough to enable importer clear goods from the ports?

The CVC has to be added to other documents such as the Import Declaration Form, the TIN and a Tax Clearance Certificate, Invoice, Bill of lading, Packing list and the Customs Single Administrative Document (SAD) with evidence of payment from the bank to begin the clearing processes.

What are the requirements for one to go into import business?

You need to do the following:

  1. Register your company with the Registrar General’s Department and obtain a certificate.
  2. Register with the Domestic Tax Department (DTD) and obtain a Tax Clearance Certificate.
  3. Apply for a Tax Identification Number (TIN) at the DTD office of Wellington Street.

What follows after obtaining the said documents

While awaiting the arrival of the goods, you may submit the following documents to ALIC at Liverpool street, an Inspection Company for a Customs Valuation and Classification Report (CVC).

  1. Original Bill of Lading/Airway Bill
  2. Attested invoice(s)
  3. Packing List

What is a Customs Valuation and Classification Report (CVC)?

A Customs Valuation and Classification Report is a report issued by an Inspection Company to an importer classifying the goods imported and also indicating their value.
